100823.name: Super Bug
100823.description:
User Summary

Drive your volkswagon bug along a road with oil slicks and puddles. Try not to run into the dotted edges and bushes. Fuel slowely runs out. Getting to certain point levels allows you to drive further.

100824.name: Super Death Chase
100824.description:
User Summary

Leave it to Exidy to break the mold of typical driving games of the late '70's. Enter Super Death Chase!

In this game each player tries to drive over and crush to death as many evil little gremlins as possible. The gremlins die and scream and leave a cross behind when squashed.

Fun mayhem in black and white Raster graphics.

100825.name: Super High-Way
100825.description:
User Summary

Super High-Way is another racing game from Taito. Sports a two speed shifter, a pedal and a steering wheel. Includes Super in the name in the hopes it will get you to spend more quarters.

100827.name: Top Runner
100827.description:
User Summary

A grand prix racing game. Uses color Raster graphics. Top Runner is a single player game. Try to get the best time. More time is awarded if you advance fast enough. Try to avoid other cars and the sides of the track.

100828.name: AMF Bowling Pinbusters!
100828.description:
AMF Bowling Pinbusters is a bowling sports-based video game.

The Wii controller allows the player to mimic real bowling by using typical bowling movements. The game environment offers mirrored balls, hot neon lights, and strobe effects. Several mini games are available such as Obstacles and Pool Bowl.

Players can choose from eight unique characters, such as the Surfer, the Drill Sergeant, Punk Rock Girl, the Cowgirl, and the Rapper – each with their own personality.

Source: Wikipedia, "AMF Bowling Pinbusters!", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100829.name: Trampoline
100829.description:
User Summary

Bounce your player up and down on a trampoline. Try to catch the stars to get points. Grab the trapezes to score more.

100830.name: Triple Hunt
100830.description:
User Summary

A different take on light gun games of the age. The cabinet has a distance of about 6 feet from the target screen. In Triple Hunt you can select three different challenges including hunting and target shooting.

100831.name: Twin Course T. T.
100831.description:
User Summary

Twin Course T.T. is a two player motorcycle racing game. It was different from a lot of the other games of the 70's genre in that it has two screens, one for each player.

Race against your opponent to score points. Race fast enough to get bonus time.

100832.name: Ultra Tank
100832.description:
User Summary

A relative of Tank. Players face off against each other with tanks. Use Battlezone typ steering to avoid mines, bullets, and shoot your opponent.

The player with the highest score at the end of the timer wins.

100833.name: Wild Wood
100833.description:
User Summary

Players use a positional rifle to shoot various forest critters that appear around trees and rocks. Score points for each successful kill.

100834.name: Witch Hunt
100834.description:
User Summary

Witch Hunt is another positional rifle game where the stooter is separated from the target screen. Hunt witches, goblins and other baddies. Score points for shooting smaller targets.

100835.name: Wolf Pack
100835.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




User Summary

This game is a rare Atari prototype. It was very unusual for its time for a couple of reasons. Most notably it was one the first games to actually feature a voice sample.

The cabinet was designed so that the player could walk all the way around the console while looking through the periscope.

Never released to the public, but still a great example of arcade history.

100836.name: World Cup
100836.description:
User Summary

Sega started early trying to corner the sports market with World Cup. It is an early competite soccer game. Use a paddle to hit the ball back and forth. Almost pong like in play, but with a light soccer theme.

100837.name: GeoSpin
100837.description:
User Summary

You control the orientation of a 3D solid. In two game modes, your goal is to match a 2D piece to the proper side of the 3D solid. Score Attack lets you race against the clock to complete the shape. Time Attack challenges you to set your best time on several different levels.

100838.name: Light Linker
100838.description:
User Summary

Light Linker is an electronic board game in which two players vie to place their "laser" pieces in a way that maximizes the length of their connections while also maximizing the number of connections they make to the border.

Light Linker won won first place in the VFS Board Game Design Competition.

100839.name: Office Rush HD
100839.description:
Feel the rush... office rush!

Welcome to the wild frontier of Corporate Office life.

Think fast in order to rise through the corporate ranks in this fun, innovative, and action-packed game.

Do not hesitate to step over bodies or jump over cubicle walls to reach your goals. The tasks that you will need to accomplish will seem simple and mundane at first, but will become non-trivial as you advance to new levels and get promoted for your achievements.

Adventures that await you will require unorthodox thinking to complete them in your quest for massive salary and the prized corner-office dream job.

Source: The Developer Website.

100840.name: Blood & Badges
100840.description:
from the publisher website

The year is 1855. Perfection is a small gold-mining town located on the east side of the Rocky Mountains, in the Kansas Territories. The state of Colorado has not yet been established. The impetuous daughter of a rail-baron left home to experience the Western Frontier. For three months there has been no word from her. Pinkerton Agents are now on the case, hired to find Victoria Featherstone amid the unknown dangers of the Wild West.

Blood & Badges contains eight Basic Roleplaying adventures, winners of the Chaosium BRP adventure contest.

100841.name: Asteroid
100841.description:
User Summary

One or two players guide their spaceship up the screen. Avoid falling asteroids and try to get to the top. If you get to the top, you get one point. If you get hit, you start back down at the bottom.

100842.name: Astro Race
100842.description:
User Summary

One to two players race against each other and other ships. Avoid comets and meteors to try to stay ahead of other racers.

100843.name: Barrel Pong
100843.description:
User Summary

Barrel Pong is basically like the original Pong. The interesting thing is the cabinet. The screen is in a big beer barrel with a deluxe looking padded cabinet below.

100844.name: Breakdown
100844.description:
Breakdown is unique in that it is technically categorized as a first-person shooter, but integrates the experiences of a fighting game into the experience as well as using auto-lock-on for shooting enemies. The viewpoint never leaves the perspective of the player, and interaction with objects, reloading of guns, and the impact of hitting the floor are all seen through this first-person perspective. Unlike other first-person shooters, interaction with objects is also all done in a realistic manner in Breakdown; ammunition is picked up by looking down and grabbing it with your arm instead of walking over it, similarly doors are opened by grabbing the handle, key cards used by swiping them over a scanner, ladders by using the arms for climbing and many others. Health and energy are replenished by consuming energy bars, sodas and hamburgers, which the player must eat while remaining in first person.
Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breakdown_(video_game),"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100845.name: Computer Space 2 Player
100845.description:
User Summary

A sequel to Nutty's Computer Space (the 1971 game that was pre-Atari.) Allows for two player play.

One of Atari's earliest titles.

100846.name: Davis Cup
100846.description:
User Summary

A tennis match game by Taito. Each player has two paddles to hit the ball back and forth. Much like pong but with two paddles.

100847.name: Solitaire (2002)
100847.description:
UNLICENSED GAME




This game is an unlicensed version of Solitaire (1990).




User Summary

Unlicensed game for NES, basic solitaire game with different card colors.

100848.name: Doctor Pong
100848.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Doctor Pong", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Doctor Pong, also known as "Puppy Pong" was an adaption of the original arcade Pong for use in a non-coin-operated environment. It was conceptualized by Nolan Bushnell, Steve Bristow, and a marketing firm to move their arcade games in to a non-arcade environment - in this case to help occupy children in pediatricians’ waiting rooms. Originally designed to be model of Snoopy's dog house with Pong built in to the side of it, when Charles Schulz declined Atari the use of Snoopy, the model was changed to a generic doghouse with a puppy looking over the top. Puppy Pong saw a limited production run and was in testing stage at Chuck E. Cheese's early locations.

100849.name: Elepong
100849.description:
User Summary

Taito's early attempt to get into the tabletop Arcade Pong genre.

100850.name: Gotcha
100850.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Gotcha (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Gotcha is a 1973 arcade game manufactured by Atari Inc.. It was Atari's fourth game after Pong, Space Race, and Pong Doubles. This was the first maze arcade game, as well as the very first video game to cause a considerable amount of controversy, predating other early examples such as Death Race by several years. The object of the game is for two players to find their way through an on-screen maze, attempting to catch each other. The controversy stemmed from the perception that the game's controls, rather than joysticks, were pink rubber bulges meant to represent breasts. The bulges were squeezed in order to control the action. This was done because some members of Atari jokingly mentioned that joysticks curiously resembled a phallus. As a result, it was decided to create a "female game" and this game was henceforth referred to as "the boob game" by company staff. Later versions of the cabinet replaced the controls with standard joysticks. The game was not well received by the public.

100851.name: Hockey TV
100851.description:
User Summary

Sega's early version of Pong with a Hockey theme.

100852.name: Leader
100852.description:
User Summary

A four person Pong by Atari. You need two or four people to play for one or two credits.

100853.name: Paddle-Ball
100853.description:
User Summary

William's take on Pong. Produced in a very simple cabinet.

100854.name: Pong Doubles
100854.description:
User Summary

Atari's version of 4 person pong. Cabinets were made in standup and coctail variants.

100855.name: Pong Tron
100855.description:
User Summary

Another black and white Pong variant from Sega.

100856.name: Pong Tron II
100856.description:
User Summary

The followup to the ever popular (along with the 30 other pong games of 1973) Pong Tron from Sega.

100857.name: Pro Hockey
100857.description:
User Summary

A pong like hockey variant. Put the puck in your opponents goal using your paddle.

100858.name: MLB 2001
100858.description:
Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer with Dave Campbell on color commentary.
Chipper Jones of the Atlanta Braves was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100859.name: MLB 98
100859.description:
MLB '98 is a Major League Baseball video game for the PlayStation and is by 989 Sports. It was released on November 17, 1997 and is rated K-A for kids to adults. Games are called by public address announcer Mike Carlucci. New York Yankees center fielder Bernie Williams was featured on the cover. Some of its features are the 30 Major League Baseball clubs, 6 playing modes, complete statistic tracking, and creating players. It has been succeeded by MLB '99, where Vin Scully began calling the games. Starting with MLB 2000, joining him is infielder Dave Campbell on color commentary.
Source: Wikipedia, "[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_'98]," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100860.name: MLB 99
100860.description:
Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer; no color commentary
Baltimore Orioles hitter Cal Ripken Jr. was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001]," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100861.name: MLB 2000
100861.description:
Again, Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer; infielder Dave Campbell joins him for color commentary starting with this game
Anaheim Angels hitter Mo Vaughn was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100862.name: MLB 2002
100862.description:
Yet again, Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer with Dave Campbell on color commentary[10]
Andruw Jones of the Atlanta Braves was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100863.name: MLB 2003
100863.description:
Yet again, Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer with Dave Campbell on color commentary
Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100865.name: Space Pirate
100865.description:
Each player starts with 25 "ovni's" in his own color, 4 blue "ovni's" and 1 white "ovni".

The players take turns placing "ovni's", which are gears, on the board, thus creating a chain of gears. The gears must placed so that the gears can still turn.

A player can block an opponent's chain by placing a pirate (blue "ovni") at the end of his chain.

The player that can make the opponent's gear turn wins.

100866.name: Freddi Fish 3: Case of the Stolen Conch Shell
100866.description:
The Conch shell which is blown to signal the beginning of the Founder's Day Festival has been stolen, and Luther's Uncle Glenny is blamed because he is the 'Grand Exalted Keeper of the Conch.' Freddi and Luther search for the real thief to clear Uncle Glenny's name and prove that he did not steal the conch. They search and investigate the suspicious characters to find out who really 'done it.'

Source: Wikipedia, "Freddie Fish", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary
This point-and-click adventure changes slightly each time, ensuring a unique procedure each play.

100867.name: Freddi Fish 2: Case of the Haunted Schoolhouse
100867.description:
When Freddi and Luther are at school one morning, a ghost appears and tries to steal Luther's action figure toy. Following the ghost to the basement of the school, they discover that the ghost is just someone wearing a ghost costume. They then plan a trap to catch the sharks, but they are missing some objects needed for the trap.

Source: Wikipedia, "Freddie Fish", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary
This point-and-click adventure changes slightly each time, ensuring a unique procedure each play.

100868.name: Freddi Fish 4: Case of the Hogfish Rustlers of Briny Gulch
100868.description:
Freddi and Luther (upon arrival at Freddi's Cousin Calico's Ranch) come to find out that her hogfish have been rustled (which in Calico's way means "someone came in and took them without asking"). Luther and Freddi head to the town square, in search of clues to find the rustlers. While in Saltwater Stella's Soda Saloon, they stumble upon their first clue - a note with a secret combination on it. Freddi and Luther figure this must be important, so they must investigate where the combination is...

Source: Wikipedia, "Freddie Fish", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary
Thus begins Freddi and Luther's quest to reveal the identity of Mr. Big, the head Hogfish rustler. This point-and-click adventure changes slightly each time, ensuring a unique procedure each play.

100869.name: Freddi Fish 5: Case of the Creature of Coral Cove
100869.description:
Freddi and Luther (on their way to Coral Cove Park) run into a large mob of sea creatures and the park's developer Marty Sardini, who are both angry yet terrified of this sea monster supposedly terrorizing the park. Freddi and Luther decide to investigate why this sea monster is scaring the citizens. Firstly, they get into Coral Cove Park (after getting a permission slip signed by the Mayor) and enter to find a chunk of green sea cheese with a large bite taken out of it. Freddi and Luther continue to examine it and it becomes their first clue to locate the sea monster's whereabouts.

Source: Wikipedia, "Freddie Fish", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary
Thus begins Freddi and Luther's quest to uncover the mystery of the monster of Coral Cove. This point-and-click adventure changes slightly each time, ensuring a unique procedure each play.

100870.name: Freddi Fish and Luther's Maze Madness
100870.description:
User Summary
Freddi and Luther have accidentally scattered all of their grandmother's kelp seeds along the ocean floor. Help Freddi collect them by navigating through a sequence of mazes while avoiding the various underwater baddies lurking about.

The player controls Freddi using the mouse or keyboard, collecting seeds and advancing into the next maze once all the seeds in a level have been collected. Upon picking up the Bubble-Shooter, Freddi can dispose of the harmful creatures of the deep.

100871.name: Freddi Fish ABC Under the Sea
100871.description:
User Product Description
Atari brings the educational series about a yellow fish named Freddi and her green friend Luther to the DS for the first time in Freddi Fish: ABC Under the Sea.
Released in 2008, Freddi Fish ABC Under the Sea is the 6th game in the Freddi Fish series for kids, and this one focuses on early letter recognition for children ages 3-5.
It focusses on skills such as letter recognition, vocabulary, spelling, counting, following directions, coloring and tracing.

videogame: Freddi Fish 4: Case of the Hogfish Rustlers of Briny Gulch
Freddi Fish 5: Case of the Creature of Coral Cove
100872.name: Freddi Fish 2-Pack
videogamecompilation: Freddi Fish 4: Case of the Hogfish Rustlers of Briny Gulch
Freddi Fish 5: Case of the Creature of Coral Cove
100872.description:
User Summary
The Freddi Fish 2 Pack includes both Freddi Fish 4 and Freddi Fish 5, two children's games involving a pair of adventurous fish intent on solving the mysteries that they encounter in their underwater world.
These single player point-and-click games focus on problem solving through the use of exploring a set number of locations, locating useful objects, and using these objects to further the plot of the story.

100873.name: Jack-the-Lad
100873.description:
A game of wheeling 'n' dealing - ducking 'n' diving - making or breaking!

Players move their character around the board, buying and gambling until there is only one player left with any money.

This is a roll-and-move game, where each space is either a gamble for gain or a penalty space.

100874.name: Treasure of Cutlass Reef
100874.description:
Ahoy mates and shiver your timbers for a epic only seen in the movies! Your the Captain of a black pirate ship and you need to use your nautical skills to manuver and attack the enemy fleet guarding the treasure! Updated to Version 1.2! - Now you can freely move across all the screen - You can select if you want to shoot upwards or downwards (key: V) - Slightly faster gameplay - Updated tutorial - Smaller ships -> larger battlefield - Your ship's size depends on your armor upgrade level - Enemy ships now can hit each other - Slightly modified enemy behavior - Other minor improvements Click Here to View Highscores!

Source: The Publisher Website.

User Summary

Simple pirate game. In this game you steer your ship, trying get it close enouh to the enemy ship(s) to board, firing your guns while doing so. Each ship that sails onto your screen has a small window, informing the player about gold treasure aboard, ships integrity, number of canons and crew. Once crew drops to 0, the ship explodes and the player earned the gold. Ships come in fleets. After defeating such a fleet, the player can buy upgrades for his ship with his freshly won goldand embark on a new journey.

100875.name: Super 7
100875.description:
Super line-drawing fun!

The next generation of line-drawing games arrives with Super 7 for the iPhone and iPod Touch.

Draw lines to combine the numbered discs and try to create 7s. Sure, it sounds simple but can you keep up once negative numbers and multipliers are thrown into the mix?

- Easy to pick up game play that will take hours to master.
- Fun power-ups!
- Real time leaderboard updates during the game.
- Automatically saves your game, simply press the home button to save your game.
- Super 7 is OpenFeint enabled:
- Online leaderboards.
- 17 challenging achievements to unlock.

Source: The Developer Website.

100876.name: Last Defender
100876.description:
You are the only one left
You are the last hope,
You are the Last Defender!

Probably the fastest pure action game with perfect controls only possible on iOS devices.

I believe a great game for iOS devices doesn't have to be complex, it must be fast, simple, fun, and of course addictive!

WHAT MAKES THIS GAME UNIQUE:

In the majority of this game I've used fonts instead of images.

WHY!?

- To make it as fast as possible with fast action at 60fps.
- To make the size as small as possible so it can be a small size universal app playable on all iOS devices.
- Depending on the type and size of your iOS device screen simply it uses different font size to make it as bright as possible on your device.

WHO WILL LOVE THIS GAME:

- People who hate loading screens
- People who hate on screen controllers that usually cover half of the screen
- People who hate puzzles
- People who just want fast pure action

FEATURES:

- Classic green screen gameplay
- Easy to play, very tough to master!
- 2 different difficulty levels (easy and hard)
- 8 different power-ups
- Game center enabled
- Auto-pause game if you press home or are interrupted by a phone call
- Free updates!

Source: The Developer Website.

100877.name: Lerne München kennen
boardgamepublisher: Stadt Buch Verlag Wolfgang Giesche München
100877.description:
This is a trivia game about the German city of Munich.

Players roll a die, move around the trails on the board across Munich (a satelite photo) and answer questions about the state. The first one to make it back to the starting space after collecting 8 cards from the different Bavarian regions and answering a final question correctly wins.

100878.name: Sneezies Easter Edition
100878.description:
User Summary

This game is an easter themed version of the original game Sneezies. The game is basically the same, but has an easter theme. You play the game by touching your screen near the small animals known as "Sneezies" to release a burst of pollen. Each sneezie getting caught by the pollen will sneeze, again releasing another burst of pollen. Your goal is to cause a chain reation, making all the sneezies sneese in one go.

This version contains 24 Classic Mode levels and 8 Challenge Mode levels

100879.name: Plutonian Poker
100879.description:
Plutonian Poker is a set collection game for 2-6 players that uses Looney Pyramids. Players claim pyramids from a shared pool, building scoring combinations with their claimed pyramids. The twist is that you are not allowed to rearrange your claims once you've made them, making the more complicated and valuable sets riskier to achieve.

Rules here: http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Plutonian_Poke...

100880.name: Pyrinoes
100880.description:
Pyrinoes is a game for two players that combines two game systems: double-six dominoes and Looney Pyramids. Players begin the game with a supply of dominoes and two colors of pyramids. Players take turns adding pieces from their supply to the chain of played pieces, either by placing dominoes or by creating a "pyrino" out of pyramids. When one person runs out of pieces, the round ends, and the winner scores points. Subsequent rounds are played until one player has earned 100 points. Pyrinoes adds strategic depth to classic Dominoes by giving the players the ability to create a desired piece, but at the risk of revealing critical information to the opponent.

Rules here: http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Pyrinoes

100881.description:
Let's Play Scotland Yard!

Which player will have the roll of the elusive Mister X? One player will function as Mister X, with the other players being detectives searching for him throughout Switzerland.

The starting station cards are shuffled and everyone draws one to determine where they will start the game. Every move is either by bus, train, or airplane. Mister X moves first and writes his move in his travel log, indicating what method of transportation he used but not where he moved. Then, each detective makes their move, cooperating with the other detectives in an effort to close in on Mister X. Mister X only reveals where he is at certain points in the game, and the chase continues until one of the detectives moves to the place where Mister X is. In this case, the team of detectives has won the game. But, if Mister X makes 24 moves without being caught, he himself wins!

Thanks to some added features and a new map, this localized version modernizes Ravensburger's classic game Scotland Yard and transfers the manhunt from London to Switzerland.
Ski areas and boat routes help Mister X to escape...

Re-implements:

Scotland Yard
100881.name: Scotland Yard Swiss Edition

100882.name: Wildlife Lotto
100882.description: This is a nature-themed Lotto game. One player is designated "caller" and every player is given a large 3x3 card featuring images of wildlife. The pictures are unique to the each card are not repeated, unlike traditional Lotto. The caller has a deck of smaller cards that have been shuffled and placed face down. One by one, the caller turns over the cards and announces the name of the animal or plant shown on the card. If someone has a match, he claims the card and places it on the corresponding art on his large card. The game is over when a player has completed all nine matches on his large card. That player is declared the winner.

100883.name: Vector TD
100883.description:
User Summary

Vector TD is one of the very first Tower Defense games on the web. You must defend your base against the evil Vectoids. You must destroy them before they reach the end of the path with the towers you build during the game.

There's seven different vectoids and several different towers you can build. Every tower is particularly usefull against a certain type of Vectoid.

100884.name: Reeelz
100884.description:
User Summary

In this game, you operate a fruit machine with 7 reeels. You can choose for either 30 or 60 combos you will have to collect. For instance: the Winter Night combo: 2x snow flake and 1x moon.

You can lock reels (which is free) while spinning the rest, or manually turn 1 reeel 1 picture up or down (which costs a credit, just like spinning all unlocked reels)

Once you managed to collect all 30 or 60 combos, the game ends and gives you a title, based on your performance.

100885.name: Occupation of the Rhineland
100885.description:
The tiniest of games I have seen, I think this one is smaller than Panzerpranks?

4 hexes one counter

The object is for the Germans to occupy the Rhineland just prior to WWII. A die must be provided by the players. The sequence is pretty simple, the German player attempts to enter the hexes of the Rhineland. Rolling on a chart to see if his move is successful. The French player does nothing. With a bad roll a French 75 goes off accidentally stopping the
German Move. The German wins if he enters all hexes of the Rhineland, the French player wins if he does SOMETHING!

Tounge in cheek, simple effective rules, I do see that it needs a little errata though.

100886.name: Ant Move
100886.description:
User Summary

An unusual mix of myrmecology and Flight Control. Ants emerge from warrens; you must draw a path for each ant to a destination hive. There are two game modes over several maps:


Death limit: Your game ends when a certain number of ants die.
Time limit: Your game ends when the timer runs out.

100887.name: World Cup Table Tennis
100887.description:
World Cup Table Tennis™ brings the basement classic to your iPhone/iPod touch! In Classic Mode, select from eight opponents, while in Tournament Mode see how good you are against all of them! In Arcade Mode, compete alone in a new twist on the traditional game. The game features, three paddles, two sound tracks and local & global high scoreboards.

Source: The Developer Website.

100888.name: X-Baseball
100888.description:
XLARGE®’s newest app “X-Baseball” is out!

A simple 8 bit baseball game for the iPhone and iPod touch.

Score points with different HITS!

Extra HITS might conceal a hidden character!

This game is Game Center enabled.

Submit your score on Game Center, and compete with others around the world!

Source: The Developer Website.

100889.name: Chule Wants a Cookie
100889.description:
Chule Wants A Cookie is the cutest farm game!

Premise of the game: Chule is hungryyyy for treats! help him collect all the animals and take them home. If he gets them all in the least amount of time, he gets a cookie! (yay!)

Solve the puzzles by aiming and throwing Chule. He will roll, smile and pick animals up until he reaches home!

Source: The Game Website.

100890.name: The Plateau
100890.description:
An Intergalactic Puzzle

The Plateau is a non-area, a corridor between worlds.

Immerse yourself in this mind-bending space challenge. Unravel tangle upon tangle of holographic orbs connected with glowing filaments as you thread your way through the unknown origins of outer space.

Source: The Game Website.

100891.name: Chromanoids
100891.description:
Chromanoids™ is a classic arcade-style space shooter, but with a colorful twist: you can only damage the oncoming ships with blasts of color that match that of the enemy. Mix and swap colors in the reservoir to make the perfect match and destroy the Chromanoid attackers.

Source: The Developer Website.

100892.name: Marvel KAPOW!
100892.description:
Smith & Tinker, the Seattle-based mobile game company, and Marvel Entertainment have released Marvel KAPOW!, a casual action-game now available worldwide on the Apple App Store. Built specifically for touch-based mobile devices, the game puts the power of Marvel’s greatest Super Heroes at your fingertips.

Players can slash with Wolverine’s claws, rebound blasts with Captain America’s mighty shield, capture with Spider-Man’s web and smite with Thor’s hammer as they vanquish an onslaught of cyber-bots based on Marvel’s greatest Super Villains. Marvel KAPOW! features 23 classic play levels, 3 boss levels, arcade mode, Game Center leader-board integration, plus continuous support and free content updates including the release of new hero powers and villain bots later this year.

Source: The Developer Website.

100893.name: MLB 2004
100893.description:
Yet again, Vin Scully is the play-by-play announcer with Dave Campbell on color commentary
Shawn Green of the Los Angeles Dodgers was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100894.name: Pathfinder Roleplaying Game Bestiary 3
100894.description:
From the publisher's website

Unleash a world of monsters! Bestiary 3 presents hundreds of new creatures for use in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. Within this collection of creatures you’ll find grave knights and savage cyclopes, kappa and colossal kaiju, clockwork killers, mysterious sphinxes, imperial dragons, and so much more! Yet not all these monsters need to be foes, as fleet-footed sleipnirs, cunning vanaras, whimsical faerie dragons and more companions from myth and modern fantasy join heroes on the path to legend. In addition, new rules for customizing and advancing monsters and an expanded glossary of creature abilities ensure that you’ll be prepared to challenge your players wherever adventure takes them!

The Pathfinder RPG Bestiary 3 is the latest indispensable volume of monsters for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game and serves as a companion to the Pathfinder RPG Core Rulebook and Pathfinder RPG Bestiary.

The 320-page Pathfinder RPG Bestiary 3 includes:
-More than 300 different monsters
-New creatures drawn from the best-known beasts of legend, literature, and Pathfinder RPG adventures
-Challenges for any adventure and every level of play
-Hordes of new templates and variants, including simple templates for on-the-fly creature customization
-Numerous lists of monsters to aid in navigation, including lists by Challenge Rating, monster type, and habitat
-Expanded universal monster rules to simplify special attacks, defenses, and qualities
-New familiars, animal companions, and other allies
...and MUCH, MUCH MORE!

100895.name: MLB 2005
100895.description:
Last game with Vin Scully as the play-by-play announcer
Eric Chavez of the Oakland Athletics was featured on the cover

Source: Wikipedia, "[
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MLB_2001]," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100896.name: Advanced Race Guide
rpghonor: 2012 Golden Geek Best RPG Supplement Nominee
rpgissuearticle: Pathfinder RPG Advanced Race Guide Preview
100896.description:
From the publisher's website:

This definitive sourcebook for the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game provides tons of new character options for all seven “core” player character races, from archetypes that allow elf characters to explore their connection to nature and magic to feats and spells that let a dwarf character carry on the legacy of his multi-generational clan or a gnome explore her connection to the First World or delve deep into her weird obsessions.

Additionally, the Advanced Race Guide offers meaty sections on a dozen “spotlight” races that make interesting and exciting player character options, such as goblins, aasimar, tieflings, dhampyrs, drow, the elemental races from Bestiary 2, and several others.

All PC-appropriate monster races in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game, including creatures from all three Bestiaries and The Inner Sea World Guide, receive race options equivalent to those presented for the core races in the Core Rulebook, for the first time allowing players to create and play characters like merfolk, grippli, duergar, stryx, and every other appropriate monster currently in the Pathfinder game.

Lastly, the Advanced Race Guide includes an extensive section that allows players and GMs to build their own custom races, either to emulate more powerful creatures that already exist in the game or to create wholly original characters unique to their campaign. This section will be the focus of Paizo’s next major Open Playtest effort, which will kick off in late fall 2011.

100897.name: MLB 2006
videogamehonor: 2006 D.I.C.E. Sports Game of the Year Nominee
100897.description:
Vladimir Guerrero of the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim was featured on the cover.
Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mlb_2006,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgamehonor: 2012 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee
2012 Golden Geek Best Thematic Board Game Nominee
2013 Nederlandse Spellenprijs Best Family Game Nominee
100901.description:
The call comes in... "911, what is your emergency?" On the other end is a panicked response of "FIRE!" Moments later you don the protective suits that will keep you alive, gather your equipment and rush to the scene of a blazing inferno. The team has only seconds to assess the situation and devise a plan of attack – then you spring into action like the trained professionals that you are. You must face your fears, never give up, and above all else work as a team because the fire is raging, the building is threatening to collapse, and lives are in danger.

You must succeed. You are the brave men and women of fire rescue; people are depending on you. This is what you do every day.

Flash Point: Fire Rescue is a cooperative game of fire rescue.

There are two versions of game play in Flash Point, a basic game and expert game.
In both variants, players are attempting to rescue 7 of 10 victims from a raging building fire.
As the players attempt to rescue the victims, the fire spreads to other parts of the building, causing structural damage and possibly blocking off pathways through the building. Each turn a player may spend action points to try to extinguish fires, move through the building, move victims out of the building or perform various special actions such as moving emergency vehicles. If 4 victims perish in the blaze or the building collapses from taking too much structural damage, the players lose. Otherwise, the players win instantly when they rescue a 7th victim.

The expert variant included in the game adds thematic elements such as flash over, combustible materials, random setup, and variations on game difficulty from novice to heroic. The game includes a double sided board with two different building plans and several expansion maps are available.
boardgameversion: English first edition with "Now Includes Firefighter Figures" sticker
100901.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
boardgameaccessory: Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Colored Miniature Bases
Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Firemen Figures
Flash Point: Fire Rescue – Realistic Victims tokens
boardgamepodcastepisode: Andy, Andrew and The Leaf Blower Man
BGA Episode 100 - Top 100 Games of All Time
Dukes of Dice - Ep. 41 - This Is Heavy Doc
Episode 67 - The Manhattan Project: Energy Empire and OrcaCon 2017
ET49: Cuando un Enano un Ladrón y un Bombero cooperan.
Low Player Count - Ep. 8 - Popular Mechanics
The Good, The Board, and the Alpha Gamer: Episode 31 Cooperative Games
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 85!

100903.name: Doodle Diver
100903.description:
User Summary

Essentially Doodle Jump in reverse, set in the sea. You play a diver descending ever deeper into the ocean. Pick up oxygen bubbles to keep up your air supply, partner with friendly animals, and avoid the dangers of the sea to go deeper than anybody else in the world!

100904.name: Biglie
100904.description:
User Summary

Biglie (Italian for "Marbles") is a marble racing game that is intended to simulate the marbles available in Barilla's Mulino Bianco snack packs in the '80s and '90s. Rather than playing on table tops and street pavement, however, the game allows you to roll marbles amidst beautiful landscapes. The app features solo play, pass-and-play, and tournament modes.

It is only in Italian.

100905.name: Medieval
100905.description:
Test your metal with Brisk Mobile's latest castle defense epic - Medieval. Out shoot and out last your enemies to claim victory. Defend your castle and your honor!
Innovative controls allow you to choose from a variety of devastating weapons. Upgrade your fortress and recruit troops to protect your land.
Survive wave after wave of enemies, protect your flag and keep your Castle from being reduced to rubble. Manage your gold and plan your strategy for dominance.
Stunning graphics and realistic sounds combine to create an immersive experience. Listen to the death cries of your opponents as you conquer their lands.

Levels of difficulty: Easy, Medium, Hard
Different Shooting Modes: Auto Fire, Show Arc, Drag Fire.
Different Troop types including war machines like Catapults and fast moving cavalry Raiders.
Stunning locations.
Unique weapons such as flaming arrows and multi-shots. Each with multiple upgrades available for maximum devastation.


Source: The Game Website.

100906.name: Doctor Who: The Mazes of Time
100906.description:
Doctor Who: The Mazes of Time is a video game for the Apple IOS platform based on the BBC TV series Doctor Who.

It is the first official Doctor Who game to be released through the App Store and will be released on the Android platform in 2011.

The story features the Eleventh Doctor and Amy arriving on a spaceship broadcasting a distress signal. From there they travel through time and space to save the Jones family from a variety of Doctor Who enemies, including Daleks, Cybermen and Silurians. The Daleks are searching for a Time Engine. The Doctor and Amy reach the Time Engine, find a Dalek Scientist and there is an explosion. From here the player has to stop the Daleks from completing their mission.

The game is played in third person 3D from a high angle view, and features the Doctor and Amy moving around rooms and mazes solving puzzles. Control is via an on-screeen joystick on the touchscreen. The player controls both Amy and the Doctor, who have different capabilities within the game, and can be swaped between at will to assist in solving particular puzzles.

Source: Wikipedia, "Doctor Who: The Mazes of Time", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100907.name: City of Secrets
100907.description:
Rex, the brave dog, accidentally falls into the underground city of moles, where he's captured, and imprisoned for espionage. His fate would be foregone if not for his friend - the not so brave and not so clever mole Moles, who is definitely not an eager beaver to come to the rescue. Breaking Rex out of jail is just the tip of the iceberg. Moles will have to face a revolution and solve many riddles to save the day.

Source: The Game Website.

100908.name: Connect6
100908.description:
User Summary

Connect6 is a two-player board game similar to Gomoku or Renju. It is played on a Go-like board of various sizes (11x11, 15x15, 19x19). After the first player makes one move, the players make two moves in a row. The goal is to get six stones of your color in a row.

The app features solo, pass-and-play, and network multiplayer. It also has several puzzles.

100909.name: Fish Galaxy
100909.description:
User Summary

Fish Galaxy is similar to Bust-a-Move, set in the deep (but colorful) sea. Features include:


42 different types of fish
6 fantasy environments
11 mini-games
42 collectible items
Game Center Support

100910.name: Pig Pop
100910.description:
How fast can you pop? It’s like popping bubble wrap with the reward of silly animal sounds! Pop the pigs and their farmyard pals in this increasingly frantic and entertainingly addictive game. Popping the animals in order gets you to the next level. The higher the level, the more animals join in. The more animals that join, the wilder the game gets. A never ending cycle of frantic farmyard fun. Time to burst that boredom! Pig Pop is available in Korean, Japanese, Chinese, French, Spanish, German and Russian.

Source: The Developer Website.

100911.name: DropZap
100911.description:
This is a NOT a color matching game! Rather, you SHRINK pieces until they disappear!

The iPhone/iPad/iPod touch version of DropZap has...

four single player game modes
a split-screen two player mode
local and global leaderboards for single player modes




Tap/drag to select the column where you want the piece to land. When any piece lands, it SHRINKS pieces below and sideways. The smallest piece (colored red) disappears when shrunk. Your game ends when the grid is full or piece(s) go beyond top. When a piece disappears, any piece(s) above it will fall, potentially resulting in other pieces disappearing, and so on. Chain reactions can be quite elaborate and are an integral part of gameplay.

Source: The Game Website.

100912.name: DropZap 2
100912.description:
This is a NOT a color matching game! Rather, you SHRINK pieces until they disappear!

The iPhone/iPad/iPod touch version of DropZap 2 has...

four single player game modes
a split-screen two player mode
local and global leaderboards for single player modes




Source: The Game Website.

This game is essentially the same as DropZap, except for a new game mode that lets you add barriers on the field.

100913.name: Space Race
100913.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Space Race (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Space Race is the second arcade game created by Atari (the first was Pong). It was released in July, 1973. The two players each control a rocket ship; the object of the game is to make it from the bottom of the screen to the top, while avoiding obstacles such as asteroids. Score is kept electronically and the background consists of a simple starfield.

100914.name: Table Tennis (Nutting)
100914.description:
User Summary

One of Nuttings last games prior to Atari's pong. A four person variant of Pong

100915.name: Watergate Caper
100915.description:
User Summary

Watergate Caper is a code breaking game from Nutting Associates. Plays in black and white.

100916.name: Guardian Rock
100916.description:
User Summary

As the guardian rock, slide your way through level after level removing would-be intruders.

100917.name: Wimbledon
100917.description:
User Summary

An early pong game from Nutting. May have been the first color version. The controls are two sliders for the front and back paddles.

100918.name: Winner
100918.description:
User Summary

An early Midway pong game. Identical game play to most variants of the time. Hit the ball back and forth in the hopes of the other player missing.

100919.name: Winner IV
100919.description:
User Summary

A four person edition of Winner by Midway. What could be more fun than playing 4 person pong?!

100920.name: Attack UFO
100920.description:
User Summary

A black and white TV monitor game from Taito where you fly a UFO and try to destroy others.

100921.name: Basketball (Taito)
100921.description:
User Summary

A very early basketball game form Taito. Each player uses a spinner to guide play.

100922.name: Coup Franc
100922.description:
User Summary

The first Atari game by Atari Europe and one of the first Cocktail cabinets.

100923.name: Coupe Du Monde
100923.description:
User Summary

Another early Atari release for the French market. A soccer themed pong game.

100924.name: Crazyfoot
100924.description:
User Summary

A soccer themed pong-like game by Midway. Try to knock the ball into the opposing goal with your paddle.

100925.name: Elimination
100925.description:
User Summary

A ping pong themed four player pong game where you try to stop the ball from going off of your side of the board (screen)

100926.name: Formula K
100926.description:
User Summary


An early Kee driving game. Use the steering wheel and shifter to drive around the maze on the screen to score points. Use a gas pedal and brakes to control speed.

100927.name: Goal Kick
100927.description:
User Summary

Another early soccer game from Sega. Kick the soccer ball vertically into the opposting goal.

100929.name: Gran Trak 20
100929.description:
User Summary

Gran Trak 20 is an upgrade to Gran Trak 10 due to the fact you can race head to head. Beat your opponent by driving better and not running into walls and other vehicles.

100930.name: Mini Hockey
100930.description:
User Summary

Another early Sega Hockey themed pong game. Try to get it in the other person's goal. This game was produced in a very small cabinet.

100931.name: Ping Pong
100931.description:
User Summary

Another Atari Pong game themed on Ping pong. Try to hit the ball back and make your opponent miss. Came in a stylish, colorful cabinet.

100932.name: Knight's Apprentice: Memorick's adventures
100932.description:
User Summary:
Memorick is a adventure game, a straight-up adventure platformer, taking place in the world of Arthurian legend. The player plays as Merlin's apprentice Memorick, a 15-year old young boy. The game features 19 levels with 26 monster types, plus 7 bosses. The player can walk/run, slid down on a shield, ride a horse, or fly on a gryphon.

100933.name: Army of Darkness Defense
100933.description:
User Summary

Follow Ash from modern day back to medieval times. Help him and the brave followers of Lord Arthur as they struggle to protect the castle and keep the Necronomicon from falling into the hands of the Deadites.

100934.name: Puppy Pong
100934.description:
User Summary

A somewhat elusive and possibly legendary pong game produced by Atari. Apparently, this is what was produced instead of Snoopy Pong to avoid issues with using the Peanuts character. It is a very rare game with an adorable cabinet.

100945.name: Dance Charades
100945.description:
You’ve seen the sprinkler, you’ve even seen the lawn mower, but you have never seen anything like this.
You get a 40 second song clip during your turn. You dance as many items as you can.
For the items other people guess correctly, you get one point.
BUT HERE IS THE TWIST! You get rewarded points from others if your dancing is awesome. Everyone else has tokens and can reward your dancing awesomeness with up to three tokens per turn.
This keeps people dancing and not just charading.


What comes in the box:
300 dance cards
Score pad
300 tokens
Audio CD with 40 songs

100948.name: AMF Bowling Pinbusters! (DS)
100948.description:
AMF Bowling Pinbusters is a bowling sports-based video game.

In the DS version, which is developed by Vir2L Studios, there are 12 different characters and many different locations. Each character has his/her own special move, which is built up using "Psyche" meter. There are four gameplay modes: World Cup, Precision, Duckpins, and Practice. In addition to these gameplay modes, the DS version also supports several multiplayer modes; pass-and-play, wireless, and Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection.

Source: Wikipedia, "AMF Bowling Pinbusters!", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100949.name: AMF Bowling World Lanes
100949.description:
In AMF Bowling World Lanes, the player uses the Wii Remote to bowl bowling balls in games played against the AI. When preparing to bowl a ball, the player can choose to throw the ball several seconds after their character has walked up to the line during their approach. The game comes with several characters that players can use and locations where players can bowl. There is also a guy called George with a long beard who you can play as only after bowling 3 perfect games. Characters include a Scottish person that wears a kilt who bowls with his plaid ball, and a Brazilian soccer player who bowls with a black and white ball. AMF Bowling World Lanes also contains several bowling mini-games.

Source: Wikipedia, "AMF Bowling World Lanes", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100950.name: Animal Kingdom: Wildlife Expedition
100950.description:
Nestled in the middle of remote Animal Island is a secret preserve where the most rare, exotic, and reclusive wild animals roam. Only the best wildlife photographers gain access to this area, so you need to impress your editor with good work and earn the trust of the furry and feathered inhabitants!

- Explore jungles, savannahs, and other wild environments!
- Use blinds and disguises to get in close for that perfect shot!
- Photograph a variety of exotic wildlife including gazelles, gorillas, and elephants!

Source: The Publisher Website.

100951.name: Animal Planet: Vet Life
100951.description:
User Summary

Animal Planet: Vet Life is a simulation title that puts you in the spotlight as a world-famous veterinary doctor. Working at clinics worldwide, the player needs to treat over 40 different animals, performing checkups and fixing ailments. Educational facts about animals and pet care are interspersed throughout the game, so the player can learn as they play.

100952.name: Bokosuka Wars
100952.description:
Bokosuka Wars (ボコスカウォーズ?) is a 1983 role-playing strategy video game developed by Kōji Sumii (住井浩司) and released by ASCII for the Sharp X1 computer, followed by ports to the MSX, FM-7, NEC PC-8801, NEC PC-9801 and Nintendo Famicom platforms. It revolves around a leader who must lead an army consisting of a phalanx of troops across a battlefield against overwhelming enemy forces while freeing and recruiting soldiers along the way, with each unit able to gain experience and level up through battle. The player must make sure that the leader stays alive, until the army reaches the enemy castle to defeat the leader of the opposing forces.

The game was responsible for laying the foundations for the tactical role-playing game genre, or the "simulation RPG" genre as it is known in Japan, with its blend of role-playing and strategy game elements. The game has also been described as an early example of an action role-playing game, an early prototype real-time strategy game, and a unique reverse tower defense game. In its time, the game was a major success in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "Bokosuka Wars", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100953.name: Zombie Close
100953.description:
A Zombie strategy game for 3 or more players, where the person who survives the longest wins.

Each player controls 1 Human and 3 Zombies. Aim of the game is to be the last Human to survive the Zombie attack. Each player takes turns to run from the shuffling Zombies, then each takes turns to move their Zombies to try and corner and bite the other players' Humans. Humans generally move a fixed number of 6 speaces, whilst Zombies move according to a dice roll (1-6). Get bitten as a Human and you still have 5 turns - or until you get bitten again if sooner - until you become a Zombie yourself. Cards take it beyond a basic roll 'n' move, with positive (for yourself) and negative (for others) special effects.

There are various cards that can either help or hinder.

100954.name: Volguard II
100954.description:
Volguard II (ヴォルガード２ Vorugado) is a Nintendo Family Computer and Virtual Console video game that is exclusive to Japan. The original manufacturer's suggested retail price of the game was 4,900 yen (approximately $30 USD). This game is a sequel to the original Volguard for the MSX despite there being no real connection to that title.

The player controls some kind of pilot who is trying to defend the Earth from an evil nation's global revolution sometime in the year 20XX. Given the assignment, the overall purpose of the game is inflitrate their base and take out their defenses and army, and then kill their leader. Enemies include a series of battle stations, various groups of aircraft, barriers, cargo planes, mechs, and other assorted enemies. Volguard II was a modified high-mobility combat mecha developed by the distant ancestors.

Source: Wikipedia, "Volguard II", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100955.name: The Ant Bully
100955.description:
The Ant Bully is a video game based on the animated movie of the same name. It was first released on July 24, 2006 alongside the theatrical release of the movie. The story and actions of the game correspond to that of the movie.

Plot

Players control the protagonist, Lucas Nickle, as he is shrunk to a miniature size and forced to work in an ant colony. He goes on many adventures throughout his backyard. From the Cactus Garden, to the Spiders lair, Lucas must overcome the challenges and become an ant. Getting in his way is the local wasp hive and the Exterminator.

Gameplay

The game is broken down into missions, though the game follows a linear design. The game is a traditional action-adventure game, with players able to use different weapons to clear a mission and advance to the next level.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Ant Bully (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100956.name: The Ant Bully (GBA)
100956.description:
The Ant Bully is a video game based on the animated movie of the same name. It was first released on July 24, 2006 alongside the theatrical release of the movie. The story and actions of the game correspond to that of the movie.

Plot

Players control the protagonist, Lucas Nickle, as he is shrunk to a miniature size and forced to work in an ant colony. He goes on many adventures throughout his backyard. From the Cactus Garden, to the Spiders lair, Lucas must overcome the challenges and become an ant. Getting in his way is the local wasp hive and the Exterminator.

Gameplay

The game is broken down into missions, though the game follows a linear design. The game is a traditional action-adventure game, with players able to use different weapons to clear a mission and advance to the next level.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Ant Bully (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100958.name: TwinBee
100958.description:
TwinBee (ツインビー?) is a cartoon-themed vertical-scrolling shoot 'em up game originally released by Konami as a coin-operated video game in 1985 in Japan. It was the very first game to run on Konami's Bubble System hardware.[1] TwinBee was ported to the Family Computer[2] and MSX[3] in 1986 and has been included in numerous compilations released in later years. The original arcade game was released outside Japan for the first time in the Nintendo DS compilation Konami Classics Series: Arcade Hits. A mobile phone version was released for i-mode Japan phones in 2003 with edited graphics.

Various TwinBee sequels were released for the arcade and home console markets following the original game, some which spawned audio drama and anime adaptations in Japan.

Source: Wikipedia, "TwinBee", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100959.name: Aquatic Tales
100959.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




Guide a school of fish from the river spring to the Ocean and protect them from running into trouble.

Use your stylus or the Wii remote to drwa the path you want your fish to follow - this path is drawn with a white ink that dissolves in the water after a few seconds.

Customize your family (in looks and features) and watch the fish's evolution throughout the game.

- 6 different worlds
- 25 beautiful and exciting levels
- Guide this family of fish to the fish sanctuary, escape from unfriendly creatures and go through many more adventures - this can all be done with a simple touch of the stylus or a slight movement with the Wii remote.

Source: The Developer Website.

100960.name: Tantei Jingūji Saburō: Yokohama-kō Renzoku Satsujin Jiken
100960.description:
Jake Hunter, known in Japan as Tantei Jingūji Saburō (探偵神宮寺三郎?, Detective Saburō Jingūji) is a mystery-adventure game series originally developed by Data East in 1987, and later developed by WorkJam and other companies.

Despite its popularity in Japan, only one of its games have been released overseas: Tantei Jingūji Saburō DS: Inishie no Kioku was retitled and released in North America on June 11, 2008 by Aksys Games as Jake Hunter: Detective Chronicles. The game was rereleased on May 26, 2009 as Jake Hunter Detective Story: Memories of the Past, which contains the original three cases with new translations to improve the original game content, plus three new cases, and a large number of unlockables including comics.

History

The first game of the series, Shinjuku Chūō Kōen Satsujin Jiken (新宿中央公園殺人事件?, Shinjuku Central Park Murder Mystery) was released in 1987 by Data East for the Family Computer Disk System. Numerous sequels have been released since then, and the series marked its 20th anniversary in 2007 by releasing a new title for the Nintendo DS. According to Enterbrain, the franchise has sold over 2,220,000 copies in total, making it one of the longest standing and best-selling Japanese adventure game series in history.

Synopsis

The search for a missing girlfriend results in the discovery of her hiding guns, and the police begin to suspect a link with an underground trafficking organization.

Source: Wikipedia, "Jake Hunter", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100961.name: Arcade Shooting Gallery
100961.description:
User Summary

Arcade Shooting Gallery is a light gun shooter for the Wii. Players control Tony and Melissa as they roam the carnival, using laser guns, bubble bomb pistols, a Fireball gun, and more in a variety of midway games. Enemies roam the amusement park and Tony and Melissa need to defeat them as they explore.

100962.name: Road Rash 64
100962.description:
Road Rash 64 for the Nintendo 64 was released in 1999. It is noteworthy because Electronic Arts did not design or publish it. Instead, the intellectual property rights were licensed to THQ, who in turn had its own studio, Locomotive Games (founded by former EA employee Don Traeger), develop the game.

Road Rash 64 was also designed similarly to F-Zero X in that the game used very low polygon models, low resolution textures, and few special effects so that the game could instead feature several dozen motorcycles, traffic models, and obstacles while being able to keep a high frame rate. The game was more focused on the combat aspects the earlier 16-bit games featured, and was ahead of its time in terms of customizable settings in a console game. N64 owners with a Ram Expansion Pak were able to choose from Wide Screen, Letterbox, and High Resolution settings in addition to the default graphics setting. The game also managed to feature five of the tracks (two of them 100% unedited) from Road Rash 3D through audio compression software.

Unlike the games before it, which used a single long road in independent locales, Road Rash 64's races took place on routes laid out through a single interconnected road system. The race routes were pieced together from branching road segments. The four corners of the game world had distinctly different geographic features. Once past the first level the races would be between or through different locales.

Source: Wikipedia, "Road Rash 64", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100963.name: Arcade Zone
100963.description:
User Summary

Arcade Zone is a party game that brings together all your favourite arcade games together for fantastic fun. Players can work their way through the Arcade Master Zone to earn a match-up against the Arcade Legend.

boardgamehonor: 2011 Origins Awards Best Miniatures Rules or Expansion Nominee
100964.description:
Warmachine: Wrath is the first expansion of Warmachine since the launch of the game's second edition which is known as MK II.

Wrath introduces an entirely new model type; the battle engine. Battle engines do not replace Warjacks or Warriors, but instead provide players with survivable, concentrated firepower and a wealth of tactical options that will appeal to a wide broad range of playstyles.

Wrath also introduces another new model type; Ranking Officers. Ranking Officers give players more reason to field Mercenaries in their armies. They provide all the benefits from a typical unit attachment, but they also transform their Mercenary units into faction units subject to all of the spells, abilities and feats the faction has to offer.

Of course, Wrath also contain new models for all the different factions.
100964.name: Warmachine: Wrath
boardgamepodcastepisode: D6G Ep 94: 2011 Best Moments & Mini Mini Reviews: Warmachine Wrath, Warhammer Badlands, & Mercs

100965.name: Pursuit
100965.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Pursuit (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Pursuit is a single-player arcade game by Kee Games, originally released in 1975. The player plays a World War I flying ace who tries to shoot down enemy planes. Gameplay relies on a first person perspective representation. Pursuit also marks the first time Atari Inc. publicly acknowledged its relationship with Kee.

The player uses a flight stick to steer the plane up, down, right, and left to get the enemy in his or her sights. The top-mounted fire button is then used to shoot the enemy plane and gain points.

100966.name: Quadrapong
100966.description:
User Summary

Atari's branded version of Elimination. This is a four player pong game and one of the first cocktail cabinets.

100967.name: Arctic Tale
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
100967.description:
Arctic Tale is a video game for the Nintendo DS, Game Boy Advance and Wii. The game is about trying to survive as a polar bear (adult or young), a walrus, a killer whale, or an arctic fox. It is loosely based on the National Geographic documentary about Arctic wildlife also called Arctic Tale.

Source: Wikipedia, "Arctic Tale (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary

The Wii version of the game is in 3D, but for the most part, identical to the GBA and DS releases.

100968.name: Qwak! (Arcade)
100968.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Qwak! (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Qwak! is a 1 player arcade game by Atari Inc., originally released in 1974. It simulates duck hunting, where by players fire at flying on-screen ducks using a rifle with a light gun attached to the end.

One duck flies across the screen at a time, giving the player three shots to hit it. A hunting dog runs out and collects the fallen prize if the player was successful with their aim.

100969.name: Rebound (1974)
100969.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Rebound (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Rebound is a 2 player arcade game by Atari Inc., originally released in February 1974. The game simulates a volleyball match, having players volley a ball back and forth over a net with their paddles. Rebound is also the first game that was cloned and released under the then hidden Atari subsidiary Kee Games, as Spike.

100970.name: Speed Race
100970.description:
User Summary

A single player black and white racing game. View is from overhead.

100971.name: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest
100971.description:
Dead Man's Chest is played on land and sea, on land the player must defeat enemies, search for treasure or for comrades, items, rumors and boat enhancements can be bought from towns. When on sea the player must travel from one island to another to play through the story or to explore the world. Sea battles can take place when the Black Pearl is steered towards other boats, during these battles the cannons are fired to damage the opposing ship and once when it has been sufficiently damaged, it's possible to board the burning ship and plunder it for food, grog and even treasures.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100972.name: Superpong
100972.description:
User Summary

Superpong is just as it sounds. A super, pong. Uses three paddles, varying ball speed, multiple serving locations and more.

Was not well received due to the glut of these games in the market. Times were moving on and Superpong was the end of an era.

100973.name: Table Hockey
100973.description:
User Summary

A Sega Hockey game. Use a ball and a paddle to hit the ball into the opposing goal.

100974.name: Tank II
100974.description:
User Summary

Between Tank and Supertank, there was Tank II. This is another game where you play tanks to avoid x's and o's and shoot the other tank.

This game required 2 players to play. There was no one player mode.

100976.name: TV Basketball
100976.description:
User Summary

An early black and white screen basketball game from midway. Use your players to try to put the ball in the basket.

100977.name: TV Pinball
100977.description:
User Summary

An early Exidy pinball game. Similar to breakout but with fixed targets. Use the ball and paddle to hit them for points.

100978.name: Are You Smarter Than A 5th Grader? Back to School
videogameseries: Are You Smarter Than A 5th Grader?
100978.description:
User Summary

Are You Smarter Than A 5th Grader? Back to School is a quiz game based on the television series of the same name. Players are asked questions from a variety of subjects including history and science. The game includes over 6000 questions in 23 categories.

Players can use 5 different game modes, and import their Mii into the game for a personal feel.

100979.name: Alley Rally
100979.description:
User Summary

A two player driving game. Drive through frantic traffic trying not to hit cars and buildings to score the most points.

100980.name: Anti-Aircraft
100980.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Anti-Aircraft (arcade game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Anti-Aircraft is a two-player arcade game by Atari, Inc, originally released in 1975. The game is sometimes referred to as Anti-Aircraft II, denoting the two-player aspect of the game

Planes fly overhead, either singly or in pairs, in random directions in the aircraft flight area. The object is to shoot down more planes than the player's opponent during the time limit.

Each player controls an anti-aircraft gun located in the lower left and right corners of the screen, respectively. A player's gun is controlled by three buttons located in each player's control station, which consists of a button for moving up, down, and firing. The up and down buttons move the gun to any one of three predefined positions.

100981.name: Balloon Gun
100981.description:
User Summary

A two player positional rifle game where players shoot rising balloons for points.

100982.name: Bullet Mark
100982.description:
User Summary

Players use Tommy guns to shoot balloons, pirates and jets.

100983.name: Crash 'N Score
100983.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Crash 'N Score", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Gameplay is a simulation of a demolition derby, in which players compete by smashing each other and running over randomly appearing numbered flags within an allotted time. Players can choose to play with or without barriers

100984.name: Destruction Derby (Arcade)
100984.description:
User Summary

A two player Crash Derby game. Run into the other cars to knock them out of action and score points.

100985.name: Goal IV
100985.description:
User Summary

A four-player pong/soccer game. Knock the ball into the other player's goal to score points.

100986.name: Hi-Way
100986.description:
User Summary

A sit down racing game, where you drive along a road and try to avoid oncoming traffic.

100987.name: Indy 800
100987.description:
User Summary

A very rare cabinet where you can race a full 8 players against each other. Each player has a steering wheel with gas and break pedals.

100988.name: Racer (1975)
100988.description:
User Summary

A black and white racing game. Avoid other cars and get as far as you can in the allotted time. It has a seat attached to the cabinet.

100990.name: Stock Car
100990.description:
User Summary

A racing game where 1 to 2 players drive around the screen trying to get flags while avoiding oil slicks and barriers.

100991.name: Tank III
100991.description:
User Summary

The third game in the Popular Tank Series. Each player plays tanks and tries to shoot the other while avoiding obstacles.

100992.name: TV Flipper
100992.description:
User Summary

A black and white video pinball. Use the flippers to hit the ball up and hit targets. Score as many points as possible before losing the ball.

100993.name: Video Action
100993.description:
User Summary

Go crazy with the whole ways to play pong. Enjoy tennis, hockey or soccer variants. UPL's attempt to jump into the pong market well after its hayday.

100994.name: Western Gun
100994.description:
User Summary

A taito game much like Gunfight. Two cowboys try to shoot each other while hiding behind rocks and cacti.

100995.name: Wheels
100995.description:
User Summary

A racing game with steering wheel, two speeds and a gas pedal. Race against computer controlled cars to get the best speed on the race.

100996.name: Wheels II
100996.description:
User Summary

A follow-up to Wheels, where you race against other cars, try to avoid crashes and get the best time. In Wheels II, you can also play against an additional human opponent.

100998.name: NCAA March Madness 98
100998.description:
NCAA March Madness 98 is the 1998 installment in the NCAA March Madness series. It was released on February 25, 1998 for the PlayStation. Former Wake Forest player Tim Duncan is featured on the cover.

Source: Wikipedia, "NCAA March Madness 98", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

100999.name: NBA Live 09
videogamehonor: 2008 Game Critics Best Sports Game of the Year Nominee
100999.description:
NBA Live 09 is the 2008 installment in the NBA Live series, developed and published by Electronic Arts. The original release date was October 7, 2008. The game features Tony Parker of the San Antonio Spurs on the cover in most markets (this is Parker's second appearance on the cover, Parker also appeared on the French version of NBA Live 07. The Wii version of the game, developed by HB Studios, is titled NBA Live 09 All-Play and launched under EA Sports' new All-Play brand exclusive to the platform. This was the last NBA Live game released for the PlayStation 2 and the Nintendo Wii.

Source: Wikipedia, "NBA Live 2009", available under the CC-BY-SA License.
